sentences_tone.text: Will Emperor Trump Bring Down The Bezos' Amazon Empire: Nationalism, Free Trade And Tariffs - Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksWill Emperor Trump Bring Down The Bezos' Amazon Empire: Nationalism, Free Trade And TariffsNov.11.16 | About: Amazon.com,

Inc. (AMZN) Gary Bourgeault Follow Long only, research analyst, portfolio strategy, mediaSend MessageSummaryNationalism drove Trump to the presidency, will it take Amazon.com to the cleaners?It's only a matter of when, not if, Trump goes after "free trade".The hidden aspect of free trade most people aren't aware of or discussing.Will Jeff Bezos' vanity ownership of the Washington Post come back to haunt him and Amazon after extreme opposition to Trump?
source: the blaze Since the thing that captured the imagination of half of America concerning President-elect Donald Trump was his commitment to securing the borders of the nation, I'm of the thought it will be at the top of his agenda when he takes office.
If it isn't, he will lose a lot of support from those that lined up behind him.

Associated with the control of the borders is immigration, which many people are convinced is part of free trade, because free trade to them isn't only about the exchange of products and services across borders, but now been has been identified as being the impetus behind the free movement of peoples.

In many nations across the world that has generated unrest as cultures and worldviews are forced to be in close proximity to one another, and that will continue to escalate as native cultures recognize the lack of will by what are perceived as unwanted invaders, which when accompanied by an increase in crime, reinforces their outlook.
Into this powder keg stepped Donald Trump, who in many ways has sympathies for native populations against what is really migration, and in the case of the U.S., illegal migration.
True immigrants and desirable immigrants come in order to assimilate and partake of the benefits of the country they're entering into.
That has changed a lot as a mixed and unknown number of criminals, and in some cases, terrorists, have entered into countries and caused death and carnage.

For that reason, and the fact a growing number of people in the U.S. consider free trade and the free movement of peoples as one, the opposition against both has reached a fever pitch, providing Trump a powerful catalyst to implement free trade and immigration policies that an obvious majority of Americans now favor.
This will have a strong impact on the retail and wholesale trade in America, and in this case I'm going to use Amazon.com

(NASDAQ:AMZN) as a representative of the overall retail sector in America, because it sells many products made outside the U.S., which could increase significantly in price if tariffs are imposed on them.
Also of importance is the ownership of the Washington Post by Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, which was brutal at times in its attacks on Trump.
That could come back to haunt Bezos because of the dislike he and Trump already have for each other - personally and professionally.
Click to enlarge source: StockCharts.com

Nationalism and free trade As I mentioned, the key takeaway for investors in a Trump Presidency as it relates to the retail and wholesale industries, is the fact free trade and free movements of people are now considered one; joined at the hip.

This is part of what has produced the populism, nationalism, and identity politics now permeating the American political landscape, and it's why Donald Trump is now President and not other Republican candidates, because he identified this as the key issue for about half of America, and successfully tapped into concerns and feelings of helplessness by some, and fury by others, to drive his way to winning the Presidency.

I'm going somewhat deep into that point because it has provided Trump with a mandate to make huge changes, including his controversial assertion he'll build a wall, and his other assertion that he'll put tariffs on a number of products he believes aren't competing fairly against American-based companies.
Many people, including labor, agree with his outlook and proposed solution to the perceived problem.

For that reason I believe he's going to do both of the things that captured the imagination of a huge block of Americans, and that means securing the borders and implementing a policy of adding tariffs to protect American economic interests.
Personally I'm not a proponent of tariffs, because consumers have spoken with their wallets that they prefer lower retail prices, which is what the current market is providing.

That said, the weak job market as measured by real wage growth has generated a lot of dissatisfaction, and concerns over the potential loss of American jobs to non-Americans has resonated with Trump's constituency because of that.
Agree with the conclusion or not, Trump won the Presidency because of these two issues, and I couldn't imagine him backpedaling on his promises to deal with both of them quickly.
Amazon.com and the Trump tariff policy A concern about Amazon is how it'll deal with higher product costs when tariffs are put in place.

The good news is those selling a lot of foreign products in general, and Chinese products specifically, will have to endure the same conditions, so there shouldn't be any competitive advantage in that regard.
Where the issue will be is in regard to higher product costs, which will without a doubt drive down sales.
That will be magnified when the American economy eventually slows down, when in response consumers tighten up their spending.
Their already hefty dead loads will have an impact as well, while a decreasing amount of disposable income for smaller ticket items, as recent data has shown is already the case, will get worse.

Amazon and its giant competitor Wal-Mart (NYSE:WMT) both sell a lot of products made in China, which appears to be the major focus of President-elect Trump; although as wages have risen there, a lot of business has been moving to countries with lower wages in other parts of Asia.
How I see it overall on the competition side, Amazon will continue to retain its e-commerce position because it still has the ability to outperform its competitors.
What will be interesting to see is if the tariffs are primarily goods made in China, whether Amazon, Wal-Mart and other retailers are already scrambling for alternative supplier outlets.
The key problem there is we don't know yet how comprehensive the tariffs will be, by which I mean if they'll be limited to China, or be imposed on imports from other countries as well.
In other words, will there be low-cost loopholes, or will they all be plugged.
The answer to that question will determine the growth of the U.S. retail industry going forward, and Amazon.com in particular.
The good news for Amazon is its retail business isn't what's driving earnings growth anyway, it's the AWS cloud service it employs.
Revenue will take a hit, but earnings, as it's represented by AWS, will continue to grow.

The Washington Post issue Since Bezos has vanity ownership of the Washington Post, and it's very liberal-leaning, it's going to be interesting if its extreme opposition to Trump could become an issue with Bezos, and by extension, Amazon.
Where this could come into play, as far as getting potential payback, would be with what Trump considers "anti-trust" practices by Amazon in the retail sector.

Since Trump is so good at making deals and negotiations, it's hard to know if he really feels this way, or is just giving Bezos something to worry about because of perceived personal attacks on Trump, and also his policies, using the Washington Post as Bezos' personal mouthpiece.
What gives it some credence is Amazon has been undergoing investigation in Europe over anti-trust issues, as well as possible tax evasion.
That at minimum provides the perception of wrongdoing, even if the company is not guilty of it.
My thought there is when measured on a global competitive basis, it would be hard to build an anti-trust case against Amazon, because it only has a relatively small piece of the overall retail pie.
By that measure Amazon is really only a small player.
What could backfire against Bezos is how Trump's constituency, which no doubt buy products from Amazon, could turn sour on Amazon because of the strong emotional tie they have to the issues.
If they lump Bezos and Amazon.com
together with the Washington Post, it could result in a significant number of consumers boycotting the e-commerce giant if they conclude the ongoing attacks on Trump are unwarranted.

Conclusion Since free trade and free movements of people are considered to be joined at the hip by a large number of people, and Trump ran his campaign with a national list message, I think there is no way he can avoid taking immediate action on those two areas after he takes office.
That means tariffs are likely to be put in place, with the only question being how wide they'll be on a country-by-country basis, and if they'll be at the same amount of each nation.
It also means he'll take action on securing the borders as well, with the strong probability he will build the wall.
This will push up the price of retail goods, and maybe the price of labor, if more jobs are made available to American citizens if the immigration crisis is slowed down.
All of this will bring about higher wages and probably an increase in American factory jobs, but it'll come with the high cost of increasing cost of inputs and an increase in inflation.

Since Amazon will not be alone in the impact, I have to assume it'll continue to compete at the same rate it has been against its competitors, but with the caveat that tariffs will probably bring a decrease in revenue, as it'll take time for better paying jobs to be created and have an economic impact from presumably a boost in the disposable income of Americans.

The real threat to Amazon in my opinion will be how Bezos responds if a lot of consumers and media outlets favorable to Trump start drawing the connection between Bezos, Amazon and the Washington Post.
That could, with the combination of decreasing sales from higher costs, be a big headwind for the company to deal with.
Also a factor is how consumers will respond if the economy slows down and they don't renew their Amazon Prime subscriptions, which are the very top spenders in the Amazon retail universe.
I think Amazon is, under these challenges, working overtime to grow its AWS cloud service even faster, as retail will for the reasons mentioned above, come under pressure in a relatively short time.
As for Trump, how quickly he is able to do this will be determined by the support he gets from his fellow Republicans and some Democrats in states with strong manufacturing industries.

With free trade being a big part of the Republican Party, it's probably going to be a tough battle to win the support he needs, especially now that immigration and free trade are considered by a large number of Americans as being one and the same.

Pressure will mount from those that gave Trump the White House to take the actions needed to protect the American economy from what are considered "unfair" competitive advantages of inexpensive imports.
Both parties will be pressured in that regard, and it may give Trump the support he needs to impose tariffs on a large number of products.
Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours.
